conclusion: Determine the magnitude of the electric force experienced by the small ball S_1 at point M.
The electric potential due to a point charge Q at a distance r is given by V = kQ/r.
The potential due to the charge at A at M is V_A = kQ/sqrt(2)L.
The potential due to the charge at B at M is V_B = kQ/sqrt(2)L.
The total potential at M is V_M = V_A + V_B = sqrt(2) kQ/L.
The potential due to the charge at A at N is V_A = kQ/sqrt(2)L.
The potential due to the charge at B at N is V_B = kQ/sqrt(2)L.
The total potential at N is V_N = V_A + V_B = sqrt(2) kQ/L.
The electric field is the negative gradient of the electric potential.
From the graph in figure (b), the electric potential at x = 0 is sqrt(2) kQ/L and at x = L/2 is 4kQ/3L.
The slope of the tangent at x = 0 gives the electric field at x = 0.
The slope of the tangent at x = 0 is calculated as (18sqrt(2) - 8) kQ/3L^2.
The electric field at x = 0 is E(0) = -dφ/dx.
The electric force on the small ball S_1 is F = qE, where q is the charge of the small ball.
From the graph in figure (c), the acceleration at x = 0 is 2g and at x = L/2 is g.
The change in acceleration is due to the change in the electric force.
The electric force at x = 0 is F(0) = qE(0).
The electric force at x = L/2 is F(L/2) = qE(L/2).
The change in acceleration is Δa = g - 2g = -g, due to the change in the electric force.
The electric field at x = 0 is E(0) = -dφ/dx.
